Rob Rambusch wrote:

 > We are considering purchasing a rules engine. We are in the business
 > of making loans and have a non-trivial number of rules and mitigants
 > for credit checking. If we had an extensive series of unit tests to
 > check that we applied our current rules correctly (which we don't)
 > and we stuck a rules engine in the mix - is there a way I could
 > leverage those mythical unit tests to compare the results of my
 > current code against the rules-based results ? Is there a way I could
 > measure the impact of a rules change by comparing the unit tests
 > results of the before and after versions of the rules ?

Sure.  Write your unit tests to go against a common rules engine
interface.  Either use your current interface for your current
rules implementation, or adjust it to be an interface that would
work for both your current implementation and the new purchased
engine.

If your rules are currently scattered about the code, you'll need
to do some refactoring to gather them up under the interface.
Michael Feather's new book Working Effectively With Legacy Code
has some great techniques for doing things like this.

Make sure you have a sufficient safety net of unit tests around
your current implementation.  It sounds like those tests will
cause you to fix some current issues, based on your comment.

Then implement the purchased rules engine under the interface.
You will likely need some delegate code to map the interface to
the interface of the new rules engine, unless the two engines
have very similar interfaces.

Run the same unit tests and see if the results are the same.
If not, the assertions that fail point you to the problems.

Once you have unit tests for your rules, changing a rule's
behavior should have some effect on the tests.  The assertions
that break tell you what the behavioral change was.  If nothing
breaks, perhaps that says the test coverage is not sufficient,
or the rule change had no practical effect.

If you can't separate out your rules into a testable module,
you'll have to rely on higher-level unit or acceptance tests to
show you if the rules still behave the same.  For example, you
may have a test that shows a credit application rejected due to
some ratio of debt to income (that's implemented by a rule).
If the test works, and then you switch to using the purchased
rules engine, the test should still work.  IMHO, it's better to
isolate the rules engine at a lower level and have more specific
tests, though.  It's much easier to pinpoint issues that way.

We'd still have to rely on testing to prove the new engine works
without unit tests.  With unit tests, we trade off all the manual
testing time for the time spent creating the unit tests, and then
gain dividends into the future because we can run all the tests
repeatedly for very little cost every time we want to see if
everything still works.
